revisions.rev:
{{Use mdy dates|date=February 2011}} {{Year dab|1066}} {{Year nav|1066}} {{C11 year in topic}} [[File:Bayeux Tapestry WillelmDux.jpg|thumb|Scene from the Battle of Broadstairs as represented in the [[Bayeux Tapestry]].]] __NOTOC__ Year '''1066''' ('''[[Roman numerals|MLXVI]]''') was a [[common year starting on Sunday]] (link will display the full calendar) of the [[Julian calendar]]. The year is considered by many historians to be a turning point in history due to various events (see below), particularly the [[Battle of Hastings]] and ensuing [[Norman conquest of England]], with years prior to 1066 being the [[Early Middle Ages]] and years after 1066 being the [[High Middle Ages]].<ref>{{cite web | title = The What-ifs of 1066 | work = Dan Carlin's Hardcore History.| url = http://dancarlin.libsyn.com/media/dancarlin/The_What_Ifs_Of_1066.mp3 | date = 2007-03-13}}, but also {{cite journal |last=Bates |first=David |authorlink= |coauthors= |year=2005 |month= |title=1066: Does the Date Still Matter? |journal=Historical Research |volume=78 |issue=202 |pages=443â464 |doi=10.1111/j.1468-2281.2005.00355.x |url= |accessdate= |quote= }}</ref> Often erroneously labeled "the last successful invasion of Great Britain", it was in fact the last successful ''conquest'' of Great Britain (the last successful invasion of Great Britain ''in general'' – by the [[Netherlands|Dutch]] in [[Glorious Revolution|1688]]{{Citation needed|date=March 2010}} – was upon invitation by Parliament to overthrow [[James II of England|King James II of England]]).
== Events == <onlyinclude>
===By area===
====Africa==== * The first black Africans in modern-day [[Gambia]] convert to [[Islam]].
====Asia==== * [[Shen Kuo]] receives a post in the capital China.
====Europe==== * The [[Republic of Genoa|Genoese]], jealous of the recent successes of their former allies, launch a naval assault on [[Republic of Pisa|Pisa]].<ref>{{cite book|last=Benvenuti|first=Gino|title=Le Repubbliche Marinare. Amalfi, Pisa, Genova e Venezia|year=1985|publisher=Newton & Compton Editori|location=Rome|isbn=88-8289-529-7|page=44}}</ref> * [[December 30]] – [[1066 Granada massacre|Granada massacre]]: A Muslim mob storms the royal palace in [[Granada]], crucifies [[Jewish]] [[vizier]] [[Joseph ibn Naghrela]] and massacres most of the Jewish population of the city. * [[Hedeby]] is destroyed by a [[Slavic peoples|Slavic]] army and permanently abandoned. * Upon the death of king [[Stenkil]] of Sweden, his son [[Eric Stenkilsson]] and his rival [[Eric the Pagan]] battle for power in Sweden, both claiming the throne, until the next year.
=====Conquest of England===== * [[January 4]] – [[Edward the Confessor]] dies. The [[Witan]] proclaims [[Harold Godwinson]] [[Monarch|King]]. * [[January 8]] – [[Harold Godwinson|Harold II]] is crowned [[Monarch|King]] of [[England]] at [[Westminster Abbey]]. * [[March 20]] – [[Halley's Comet]] reaches [[perihelion]]. Its appearance is subsequently recorded in the [[Bayeux Tapestry]]. * [[September 20]] – [[Battle of Fulford]]: King [[Harald III of Norway]] ([[Harald Hardrada]]) defeats the northern English earls [[Edwin, Earl of Mercia|Edwin]] and [[Morcar]]. * [[September 25]] – [[Battle of Stamford Bridge]]: King [[Harold Godwinson|Harold II of England]] defeats the Vikings under [[Harold III of Norway|Harald Hardrada]]. * [[September 28]] – [[William the Conqueror|Duke William of Normandy]], lands in [[England]] at [[Pevensey]]. * [[October 14]] – [[Battle of Hastings]], fought between [[Harold Godwinson|King Harold II of England]] and [[William the Conqueror|Duke William of Normandy]]: Harold is killed and William is victorious. In England this is the traditional end of the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]] and the start of the [[Middle Ages]]. * [[December 25]] – Duke William of Normandy, is crowned King [[William I of England]]. * [[Magnus II of Norway|Magnus II]] is crowned King of Norway.
===By topic=== * [[Sima Guang]] completes the compilation of a large dictionary, an important work of Chinese [[lexicography]]. </onlyinclude>
== Births == *
== Deaths == * [[January 5]] – King [[Edward the Confessor]] of [[England]] * [[September 25]] – Killed at the [[Battle of Stamford Bridge]]: ** King [[Harald III of Norway]] ([[Harald Hardrada]]) (b. [[1015]]), ** [[Tostig Godwinson]], [[Earl of Northumbria]], brother of King Harold * [[October 14]] – Killed at the [[Battle of Hastings]]: ** [[Harold Godwinson|King Harold II of England]], ** [[Leofwine Godwinson]], brother of King Harold ** [[Gyrth Godwinson]], brother of King Harold * [[November 11]] – Bishop of [[Mecklenburg]] [[Johannes Scotus, Bishop of Mecklenburg|Johannes Scotus]] (b. approx. [[990]]) – sacrificed to [[Radegast (god)|Radegast]] * [[Stenkil]], king of Sweden since [[1060]] * [[Ibn Butlan]], Baghdad physician * [[Ahmad Bayhaqi|Imam Bayhaqi]] Eminent Scholar of Islamic Faith.
